The emission stability of the phosphor at elevated temperatures is an important factor determining the phosphors suitability for practical applications. The high power near-UV or blue LEDs can heat up to temperatures as high as 150 °C; therefore, the phosphor considered for such application should emit at this temperature efficiently. Besides, the temperature-dependent integrated emission spectra can also be used to determine the thermal quenching TQ 1/2 (this value shows the temperature at which phosphor loses half of its efficiency) and thermal quenching activation energy Ea values.
